Body:
BC-FEATURES-BJT25-COX 
    

      COX NEWS SERVICE FEATURES BUDGET
      c. 1999 Cox News Service

   These feature stories are moving today to clients of the New
York Times News Service. Stories are for release Tuesday, May 25,
1999, unless otherwise embargoed.

   COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION

   So specialty editors won't have to look at every day's budget,
Cox's features budgets have daily themes according tothis schedule:

   TODAY: Technology

   Tuesday for Wednesday: Automotive and personal finance

   Wednesday for Thursday: Food, CD reviews, video reviews

   Thursday for Friday: Movie reviews, travel, books, fashion, and
home & garden

   Friday for Saturday: Religion and science & health

   In addition, separate budgets move daily with spot news, sports,
business and commentary.

   Stories are moving in the category they're listed under. Stories
moving to duplicate categories are marked. An ETA is given if a
story will move after 8 p.m. Eastern.

   If you have questions or need a resend, please call CoxNet, the
Cox News Service, at 404-526-5456.

   LOOK ON THE WEB: Stories marked as a CoxNet layout are available
for purchase in paginated form: www.nytsyn.com/pageexpress.

   TECHNOLOGY

   COXNET PERSONAL TECHNOLOGY PAGE

   EDS: This is the CoxNet PTECH page for the current week. This
layout is available after 2 p.m. EDT on Tuesday.

   COXNET PTECH 0525 _ The computer does two things that make
genealogy simpler, more fun and more efficient: It organizes
records, and it links hobbyists through the Internet for the
exchange of ideas and information. (Cummings, Dayton Daily News)
Art includes one 4-column color illustration of a family tree on a
computer chip board.

   WITH

   TECH BRIEFS _ If your child has not taken to reading with the
same enthusiasm and skill as he has taken to video games, there's a
new Web site that might help. (Clothier, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) Art includes one 2-column color photo of a
Web site of Sylban Learning Foundation.

   TECHNOBUDDY _ Can we have some privacy? That's what folks will
tell you, if you ask about the fears they have of the Internet and
the Web. (Husted, Atlanta Journal-Constitution.) Art includes 1
column color sig of columnist.

   TRENDS _ Parents have mixed feelings about kids exploring the
Internet, according to a news study. (Clothier, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) Art includes one 1-column color illustration
of a computer.

   DOMAIN-NAMES _ AUSTIN, Texas _ The process of registering a
domain name, which is simpler than it used to be, is still not as
effortless as it could be. But soon, it will be a little easier and
likely cheaper if a plan to include more registrars and add new
domain suffixes is successful. (Gallaga, Austin
American-Statesman). MOVED.

   TECHNOBUDDY_ I was thinking about pocket calculators the other
day. I remembered, back in the 1970s, saving up about $400 to buy a
Hewlett Packard calculator. It was an amazing device then. It could
add, multiply and divide, as well as do all sort of math problems
that would have made my high school trig teacher proud. It was a
marvel of the time _ all that power packed into a gizmo small
enough to fit into my jacket pocket. Nowadays, of course, you can
find more powerful pocket calculators for $4 hanging in those
little shrinkwrap packages as you stand in the grocery store
checkout line. That's one of the real marvels of technology _ how
prices drop so fast. Think of any gadget you care to mention _
microwave oven, VCR, color television _ and, if you are old enough,
you'll be struck by how expensive it once was and how cheap it is
now. While prices for cars, houses and tee shirts have zoomed up
over the years, gadget prices invariably have dropped. (Husted,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED.

   TECHTOOLS _ We gather today to examine a thing called
RadioMouse. RadioMouse is not, as you might think, a mouse with an
AM-FM radio in it, although I'm sure that if one hasn't been
marketed it soon will be. Rather, RadioMouse is another wireless
mouse. It has this small distinction, at least: It's the first
wireless mouse I've tried. (Warner, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).
15. MOVED.

   NETWATCH _ Web sites can help in tracing ancestors. (Katz,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED.

   CYBERSCENE _ What's new on the Web. This week: For people who
spend most of their working day and some of their personal time
connected to the Internet, the Web becomes part of the daily
routine. Just as someone who travels a lot in the real world _ the
place where it rains and the sun shines _ get to know the
territory, those of us who spend half our waking hours in
cyberspace get to know the territory some. We have sites that are
part of our practical every day working life. For instance, I check
the weather by zapping over to The Weather Channel
(www.weather.com); or for looking up a street address, e-mail
address, or phone number go to Switchboard (www.switchboard.com),
or to find the best way to get to a business across town use
Yahoo!'s excellent mapping service (maps.yahoo.com/py/maps.py).
(Husted, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 17. MOVED.

   TECH-MEDIA _ If you fear the Y2K bug, this may be the book for
you. ``Crisis Investing for the year 2000'' is a guide on how to
protect your finances if computers _ especially those on Wall
Street _ start to go haywire after midnight on Jan. 1. ``Preparing
yourself and your investments for Y2K is not the act of a fringe
survivalist,'' say authors L. Jay Kuo and Edward M. Dua in the
promotion blurb on the jacket of their book. ``Such measures are
the practical precautions of an informed realist.'' Here's some of
the authors predictions: Y2K will disrupt time-sensitive industries
such as banking and stock trading; Y2K will hurt companies
dependent on computer automation for making products and companies
dependent on overseas investments will be hurt because most
countries are ill-prepared for the millennium bug. (Haddad, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 14. MOVED.

   MAC-REPORT _ News on Apple and its products. This week: There
are some areas, dare I say it, in which the PC world commands a
lead over Apple Computer technology. One of the more significant is
voice-recognition software, a technology that Apple Computer once
pioneered. But Apple Computer is starting to close the gap, much to
the relief of many Mac users. (Haddad , Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 15. MOVED.

   TECH-REPORT _ Tech briefs on new products and developments. This
week: How often has this happened: It's 8 p.m., you realize The
Nanny is a rerun and the Braves are on the West Coast. You flip
over to the A&E channel for relief only to find its ``Accounting
Giants Week'' on Biography. Now, A&E is giving you a chance to have
a hand in the occasional program selection. Biography is getting
interactive. Until June 1, people can type www.biography.com into
their Web browser and have a little say in what they see. Viewers
will pick the bios shown over the next several months. The
by-demand hour-long shows will start airing Monday, July 12, on the
8 p.m. A&E channel series. (Clothier, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 20. MOVED.

   POWERUSER-COLUMN _ A regular series of columns for advanced
computer users. Not available this week: (Yandel, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution).

   ONLINE-GENEALOGY _ Once upon a time, if you wanted to research
your family tree, you had to travel from library to library. But
the Internet is making genealogy a hobby you can pursue from home,
with many resources now online. (Cummings, Dayton Daily News). WITH
ILLUSTRATION. MOVED.WALKMAN-ANNIVERSARY _ As Sony celebrates the
30th anniversary of the personal stereo, the Walkman, it introduces
the MZ-R55 portable MiniDisc recorder/player. (Dayton Daily News).
6. MOVED.

   LIFESTYLE

   VIOLENCE-LYRICS _ Can a rock band be blamed for the deadly
actions of fervent fans? Of course. The finger-pointing has
happened time and again. But does that mean there's a provable
cause-and-effect relationship when a young fan goes over the edge?
The courts keep saying no. Everything that Eric Harris and Dylan
Klebold listened to fell under societal scrutiny after they shot to
death 12 classmates and a teacher at Columbine High School in
Littleton, Colo., and then killed themselves. Caught in the middle
of the controversy this time was Marilyn Manson. (Riemenschneider,
Austin American-Statesman). 40. WITH PHOTO ILLUSTRATION.

   BOOKS-SELFHELP _ Call it ``He Smirked, She Smirked.'' No longer
satisfied just to steal scenes, comedians Ben Stiller (''There's
Something About Mary'') and Janeane Garofolo (''The Larry Sanders
Show'') have taken a swipe at self-help books, relationship guides,
even the ubiquitous ``He Said, She Said'' columns in a new book
entitled ``Feel This Book.'' Taking turns discussing _ and dissing
_ each other and the other sex, the duo cover such essential topics
as compassion (''Is It Overrated?''), money (''How Can I Make it
Off My Spouse?'') and role playing (''I'm Not You and I Never Will
Be _ Thank God!'') We talk to Stiller and Garofolo. (Vejnoska,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 15.

   NEWS FOR KIDS

   NFK-CHECKITOUT _ Flit and flutter Do you like to chase
butterflies? Before you trap that butterfly in your net, learn more
about these beautiful creatures on the Net at
www.mesc.usgs.gov/butterfly/butterfly.html. (Atlanta
Journal-Constitution ). MOVED.

   NFK-NEWSFLASH _ A student opened fire in a Georgia school last
week, exactly one month after the attack at Columbine High School
in Colorado. Police said a 15-year-old boy wounded six of his
classmates at Heritage High School in Conyers, about 20 miles east
of downtown Atlanta. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution). MOVED.

   NFK-FEATURE _ My name is Zulu, and I'm an 8-year-old African
lion who lives at Zoo Atlanta. You might remember my 1 1/2-year-old
cub, Kariba, who was in News For Kids a few months ago. (Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). MOVED.

   ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS

   NEWSSTAND _ Periodicals on the newsstands this week. (O'Briant,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers

   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service
